title: Are there anything like a Musketproof Cuirass from the 16th, 17th or 18th century? I mean somthing like an ar500 just made from steel, thick enough to prevent Musketbulltets from penetrating the Body? (a medieval plate carrier) - Quora

response.answer_text: This is literally what “proofed” armor was, for the 16th and early 17th century. It was armor either “half proofed” aka pistol proof, or full “proofed” meaning it could resist longarms. It was primarily just the breastplate being thick enough as if you increased the other parts to be thick enough the weight would be too high. There are some later pieces that were resistant to bullets but by that time it was harder to make them reliably protect you.   The two first armors appear to be 16th to 17th century. The last armor is 19th century.  Notice, it survived a glancing bullet or 2. But when it got hit with a cannon, well there was a bit of a hole in his chest.

Yes there was. It was very expensive, usually quite decorative, and often had a second plate which was placed over the first is some sort of reinforcement. Musket vs. Medieval Armor Here is a video showing it resisting musket/arquebus balls. There is a better one out there somewhere but I couldn't find it. It's an hour-long documentary showing the making breastplate in exactly the same manner as the 16th century, and proofing it. You might be able to find it on YouTube.
